title: Take Me Out to the Ballgame: Find the Probability
question_text:
The table below shows the distribution of the types of tickets that were sold for a minor league baseball game.
If one ticket holder at this game is selected at random to receive free tickets to an upcoming game, what is the probability that the winner is seated in either a field box seat or in the bleachers?
If one ticket holder at this game is selected at random to receive free tickets to an upcoming game, what is the probability that the winner is seated in either a field box seat or in the bleachers?
tables:
Seat TypeField BoxReserved BoxGrandstand
Reserved		BleachersPicnic Area / Standing
Relative Frequency38%20%14%6%
solution:
Since one ticket can only be for one seat in one section, we know that the different types of tickets are mutually exclusive. The relative frequencies must add up to $100\%$.

Do not make the mistake of thinking that because the relative frequency for bleacher seats was left empty that the relative frequency must be zero. Start by finding the relative frequency for bleacher seats:

$$100\% - 38\% - 20\% - 14\% - 6\% = 22\%$$

To find the probability that the randomly selected winner will be from a field box seat or a bleacher seat, simply add the individual probabilities:

$$p(\text{field box or bleacher}) = 38\% + 22\% = 60\%$$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. It represents the probability that the winner will come from the picnic area/standing section.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. It represents the probability that the winner will come from the bleachers.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. It represents the probability that the winner will have a field box seat.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. It represents the probability that the winner will have a seat of any type other than picnic area/standing.
